bestBHT.bht: The betrayer, Judas, promised to betray Jesus without immediate payment, waiting for the opportune time to carry out his betrayal. He agreed to avoid causing an uproar among the people, as requested by the Jewish authorities. This sinister act was influenced by the entrance of Satan himself. Judas, continuously seeking the perfect chance, claimed familiarity with Jesus' habits. The rabbis considered Judas' treachery as a providential act justifying their own plots, while Matthew specifies thirty pieces of silver as the agreed-upon price.

Henry Alford: The only matters requiring notice are,—the words when they heard [it], i.e. ‘the proposal,’—"
promised, implying, as does the word in Luke, that the money was not paid now, either as full wages, or as earnest-money,—but promised;
and paid (most probably) when the Lord was brought before the Sanhedrim, which was what Judas undertook to do.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: That he should avoid an 'uproar' or 'riot' among the people, which probably was made an essential condition by the Jewish authorities, was thus assented to by the traitor."
Satan entered," to put him upon this hellish deed.
What passed between Annas and our Lord during this interval the beloved disciple reserves till he has related the beginning of Peter's fall.
Marvin Vincent: He sought [εζητει] . Imperfect tense. He kept seeking: busied himself continuously from that time.
Conveniently [ευκαιρως] . Might find a good opportunity [καιρος].
Archibald T. Robertson: No doubt the rabbis looked on the treachery of Judas as a veritable dispensation of Providence amply justifying their plots against Jesus.

He claimed that he knew enough of the habits of Jesus to enable them to catch him 'in the absence of the multitude' (Luke 22:6) without waiting for the passover to be over, when the crowds would leave.
Mark merely notes the promise of 'money' while Matthew mentions 'thirty pieces of silver' (Zechariah 11:12), the price of a slave.
John Gill: That such an opportunity offered, and from such a quarter, by one of his own disciples; so that it might be done more secretly and effectually, and with less blame to themselves.
And what was agreed upon were thirty pieces, or shekels of silver.
Henceforward he sought the most fitting opportunity, and the best season of betraying his master into the hands of these men.

bhtAttempts.bht: When the betrayer, Judas, heard the proposal to betray Jesus, he promised to do so without immediate payment, but with the assurance that he would be paid when Jesus was brought before the Sanhedrin. Judas agreed to avoid any uproar or riot among the people, which was likely a condition set by the Jewish authorities. It is said that Satan entered Judas to incite this hellish deed. Seeking a good opportunity to carry out his betrayal, Judas continuously busied himself with this task. The rabbis saw Judas' treachery as a providential act justifying their plots against Jesus, and Judas claimed that he knew enough about Jesus' habits to catch him without waiting for the passover to be over. Mark mentions the promise of money while Matthew specifies thirty pieces of silver, alluding to Zechariah 11:12.

The betrayer, Judas, heard the proposal and promised to betray Jesus without immediate payment, but with the assurance of being paid later. Judas agreed to avoid any uproar among the people, as the Jewish authorities likely required. It is said that Satan entered him to incite this hellish deed. Judas continuously sought a good opportunity to carry out his betrayal, claiming he knew enough about Jesus' habits. The rabbis saw Judas' treachery as a providential act justifying their plots. Mark mentions the promise of money while Matthew specifies thirty pieces of silver, alluding to Zechariah 11:12.

The betrayer, Judas, promised to betray Jesus without immediate payment, waiting for the opportune time to carry out his betrayal. He agreed to avoid causing an uproar among the people, as requested by the Jewish authorities. This sinister act was influenced by the entrance of Satan himself. Judas, continuously seeking the perfect chance, claimed familiarity with Jesus' habits. The rabbis considered Judas' treachery as a providential act justifying their own plots, while Matthew specifies thirty pieces of silver as the agreed-upon price.

Judas, the betrayer, heard the proposal to betray Jesus and agreed to it on the condition of receiving payment at a later time. He pledged to avoid any uproar among the people, as dictated by the Jewish authorities. It is said that Satan entered him, driving him towards this wicked act. Continuously seeking a suitable opportunity, Judas claimed knowledge of Jesus' habits in order to apprehend him without waiting for the passover to end. While Mark mentions the promise of money, Matthew specifies thirty pieces of silver as the agreed amount.

Judas, the betrayer, agreed to the proposal of betraying Jesus, promising to do so with the expectation of future payment. He consented to avoid causing an uproar among the people, as demanded by the Jewish authorities. It is believed that Satan had entered Judas, driving him to carry out this diabolical act. Continuously seeking a fitting opportunity, Judas claimed to be familiar enough with Jesus' habits to apprehend him without waiting for the passover to end. Mark mentions the promise of money, while Matthew specifies thirty pieces of silver, alluding to Zechariah 11:12.
